noun.description: The service rendered or the sum of money paid by a vassal to a superior.
A clause in a charter which specifies such a service or payment.

origin: Early 17th century; earliest use found in David Hume (1558–?1631), political theorist and poet. From post-classical Latin reddendo clause in a charter which specifies the service rendered or the sum of money paid by a vassal to a superior from classical Latin reddendō, ablative of reddendus, the first word of the post-classical Latin clause reddendo inde annuatim, etc.
